Info.title: 大學機構典藏推展之策略與實踐:以國立政治大學圖書館為例

Abstract:
Many academic libraries are often faced with the challenge of developing and
popularizing the use of an institutional repository. This paper discusses the various issues
associated with providing repository services, and explores the current strategies and 
organizational activities employed by libraries when introducing them. It presents the
experiences and results of the National Chengchi University libraries in handling the tasks
of institutional repository development, promotion, and marketing

General Computer Science.reason: While not deeply technical, the paper touches on general concepts related to information management and system implementation within a library context.

Computer Science (miscellaneous).reason: This is a broad category that can encompass aspects of the paper that don't fit neatly into other specific CS domains. The development and management of a digital repository involves various computational considerations.

Artificial Intelligence.reason: The abstract doesn't mention AI. No relevance.

Computational Theory and Mathematics.reason: The abstract doesn't mention any theoretical or mathematical aspects.

Computer Graphics and Computer-Aided Des.reason: The abstract doesn't mention graphics or CAD.

Computer Networks and Communications.reason: While repositories are accessed over networks, the abstract doesn't focus on networking aspects.

Computer Science Applications.reason: Institutional repositories are a specific application of computer science principles to manage and disseminate scholarly information. This is a core aspect of the paper.

Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition.reason: The abstract doesn't mention computer vision or pattern recognition.

Hardware and Architecture.reason: The abstract doesn't focus on the underlying hardware or architecture of the repository system.

Human-Computer Interaction.reason: The abstract doesn't explicitly mention HCI, but the promotion and marketing of the repository implicitly involve considerations of user experience and interface design.

Information Systems.reason: Institutional repositories are a type of information system. The paper directly addresses the development, implementation, and management of such a system.

Signal Processing.reason: The abstract doesn't mention signal processing.

Software.reason: Repositories are software systems. The development and maintenance of the repository software is relevant, although not the primary focus.
